entry.title: Comment 6
entry.content: Ok, I've updated the design doc bug list to take care of this. The list also needs another update to cover TLS issues, and new fingerprinting issues introduced in FF4.

entry.title: Comment 3
entry.content: Yes arma, i wonder too, because most of end non-advanced users are using Skype, without ticking out "User 80,443 ports for connections" box in Skype settings. This realy breaks "just Setup&Use" mode.

entry.title: Comment 2
entry.content:
Vidalia picks port 443 by default on Windows, and port 9001 by default on OS X and Linux (since in those cases it can't pick a privileged port without permissions).

You can go into the Vidalia "sharing" settings window and change the port. But that defeats some of the point of a preconfigured bundle. I wonder how much of an issue this conflict is in practice.

entry.title: Comment 1
entry.content: Great stuff, but which bridge port will be used by default? 443? Remember that Skype on windows uses 443, 80 ports for relaying.

entry.title: Comment 14
entry.content: There isn't one. These browser bundles do not support PowerPC macs.

entry.title: Comment 12
entry.content: These bundles do not support powerpc macs.

entry.title: Comment 7
entry.content: While ghostery sounds decent, it seems no one has analyzed the codebase to see what it actually does or reports back to the ghostery servers.

entry.title: Comment 102
entry.content: I don't understand sth. Why has the industry chosen to 'ignore' returned errors on the crl queries? Are there a lot of false positives? And is it i.a. a calculated risk they are willing to take?
